journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Coupling in-flight trajectory planning and flocking for multiple autonomous parafoils

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, Technion City, Haifa, Israel

author-notes.corresp: Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, Technion City, Haifa 32000, Israel. email: pgurfil@technion.ac.il

abstract.p: Much effort has been invested during the past decades in design of parafoils for a wide range of payloads and in development of means for their guidance. Existing parafoils are capable of autonomous navigation using the global positioning system and other onboard sensors. The purpose of this study is to explore the advantages of coordination among multiple autonomous parafoils. Each parafoil is able to navigate to the target on its own by following a real-time-generated reference trajectory. A new method for trajectory generation is presented and behaviour-based rules are developed that control the relative motion of the descending parafoils. The set of simple rules results in an emergent behaviour known as flocking. The coupling between trajectory following and flocking is studied in a multiagent simulation. The simulation uses a realistic six-degrees-of-freedom model of a heavy cargo parafoil. The obtained results demonstrate the possibility of flocking behaviour for guided parafoils. The flocking rules ensure safe separation between the vehicles headed for the same target and allow the parafoils to follow a reference trajectory as a group.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Technology advances during the 20th century revolutionized the airdrop practices by allowing precision aerial delivery. One of those advances was the introduction of ram-air parachutes, also known as parafoils, in the mid 1960s. Parafoils, contrary to the round parachutes, are lifting wings. They have much higher gliding ratio and better manoeuvrability than parachutes, thus providing better control of the flight path. The global positioning system (GPS) and advances in microelectronics and microelectromechanical systems have provided miniature on-board sensors and computers, rendering the development of fully autonomous parafoils possible. Simultaneously, precision aerial delivery technology was identified as a vital capability by several military and space exploration institutions. Consequently, in the past decades, guided parafoils became an object of an increased research interest.

Among the challenges for the designers of ram-air parachutes is increasing the payload capacity of the parafoils while improving their glide ratio. For example, NASA's X-38 program, cancelled in 2003, involved development and testing of a 7500 ft2 parafoil for landing a 25 000 lb spacecraft [1]. In Europe, the FASTWing CL (foldable adaptive steerable textile wing for delivery of capital loads) project [2], ongoing since December 2006, aims to develop a self-navigated system for cargo up to 6000 kg. A 42 000 lb parafoil system was demonstrated in USA in 2009 [3].

Another major scientific and engineering effort was directed towards the development of autonomous guidance systems and algorithms that would enable precise delivery of the payload to the planned destination in spite of uncertainties in the wind data and the parachute characteristics. The accuracy goal set by the US Army was landing within 100 m of the target under adverse weather conditions and with deployment altitudes above 25 000 ft [4–6]. For lighter – below 150 lb – payload category, even a tighter objective of 10 m at 80 per cent circular error probable (CEP) is now considered [3].

The subject that received less attention is coordination and task management of multiple parafoil systems. Nevertheless, proper interaction among the parafoils is essential since many airdrop scenarios involve coordinated delivery of multiple payloads to multiple destinations. Operation of multiple units that share airspace is required to be collision free; hence, it is necessary to employ coordination and collision avoidance algorithms.

The domain of autonomous parafoil systems is closely related to other domains of robotics and artificial intelligence (AI). A parafoil vehicle equipped with an airborne guidance computer can be viewed as an intelligent agent with sensing, actuating, and information processing capabilities. As such, it can be aware of and interact with other agents within its vicinity. The research of AI behaviours and group interactions evolved concurrently with the parafoil technology. Traditionally, the research in robotics and AI considers wheeled robots, human-like or animal-like robots, autonomous computer-generated agents, and characters. Lately, the models considered were extended to various land, air, and underwater vehicles. Techniques from the AI world can also be applied to the design of interactions and autonomous coordination between parafoils.

This study considers a large-scale parafoil for 6000 kg payload modelled using available data on the FASTWing and FASTWing CL parafoils [7]. The research focuses on design of guidance laws for precision landing of the parafoil; then, a behavioural strategy for relative motion control of multiple parafoils is proposed and its effects on the baseline guidance are investigated. Formulation of the behaviour-based rules for coordinated descent of multiple parafoils constitutes the main contribution of this study.

sec.title: 2 RELATED WORK
sec.p: An inflated parafoil canopy is essentially a low aspect ratio wing with a characteristic arc anhedral. Study of its aerodynamics began after Jalbert published his invention of the ram-air-inflated parachute, or parafoil, in 1964 (US Patent no. 3 285 546). Several researchers reported results of wind tunnel investigations of parafoil characteristics [8–11]. Iacomini and Cerimele [12, 13] presented aerodynamic characteristics of a large-scale parafoil estimated from a series of flight tests performed during the X-38 program. Other researchers employed an analytic approach for the derivation of the parafoil's aerodynamic properties. A thorough treatment of a gliding parachute flight mechanics and aerodynamics is presented by Iosilevskii [14] in his report. In reference [15], Iosilevskii analysed the longitudinal trim and stability of a parafoil and derived the limits on its centre of gravity (CG) and minimal lift coefficient. He also used the extended lifting-line theory to derive approximate expressions for the aerodynamic coefficients of a gliding parachute [16]. Jann [17] compared the aerodynamic coefficients predicted by the lifting-line theory with parameters estimated from flight tests. Slegers and Costello [18] modelled a parafoil canopy as several joined panels and computed the aerodynamic forces and moments by summation of the lift and drag forces experienced by the panels. Lingard [19] provided a review of ram-air parachute design and aerodynamics, offering a valuable insight into parafoil performance and dynamics.

Concurrent with investigation of the parafoil aerodynamics, equations of motion (EOM) for simulation of the parafoil–payload system were developed. In a 1968 NASA technical report [20], Gamble developed two sets of six-degrees-of-freedom (DOFs) rigid-body EOM for the parafoil and the payload, adding the constraints of the risers and suspension lines. In the years to come, various mathematical models were considered, ranging from three to nine DOF.

Models with nine DOF comprise the high end of high-fidelity simulations [18, 21, 22]. They consider the parafoil canopy and the payload as two rigid bodies with position of the payload constrained by the suspension lines. Thus, these models include the six DOFs of the parafoil plus three rotational DOF of the payload.

It can be claimed that the payload roll is effectively constrained by the tension of suspension lines, so that the payload is only free to pitch and yaw. Therefore, eight DOFs are sufficient to fully describe the motion of a parafoil–payload system [23, 24].
For many applications, however, the relative motion of the parafoil and the payload can be neglected. Then, a parafoil–payload system can be treated as a rigid body using 6-DOF EOM [25–28].

Even a more simplified modelling approach is usually employed for motion planning or guidance design [29–32]. A parafoil motion is described by purely kinematic relations based on the assumption of equilibrium glide. Models of this type do not need a full aerodynamic database, but the knowledge of the equilibrium glide ratio, the gliding speed, and the maximum rate of turn is required. As a crude approximation, the glide parameters can be assumed constant throughout the flight. However, the turns usually comprise a substantial portion of the descent. Neglecting their effect on the glide angle would lead to large errors in prediction of the gliding trajectory. Jann [29] compares a 3-DOF model assuming a constant speed and glide ratio to a 4-DOF model which includes a DOF in roll. Either the rate of turn or the bank angle can be viewed as a control input. Parafoil response to lateral control can have a large time constant; to account for the lag in response, the quasi-steady model can be supplemented by linear dynamics. In references [29] to [31], a first-order lag between the control deflection and the bank angle is assumed.

Most authors include the added, or apparent, mass terms in the EOM. A general analysis of the EOM of a vehicle in a moving fluid giving rise to those terms is performed by Thomasson [33]. Lissaman and Brown [34] and Barrows [35] solve the problem of identifying the centre of apparent mass of a parafoil and provide parametric forms for estimating the apparent mass terms.

Early parafoil guidance concepts developed in the 1960s to 1970s relied on a radio beacon placed at the target that allowed the gliding parachute to home in on its signal [36]. Introduction of the GPS enabled development of more sophisticated guidance laws. A guidance, navigation, and control concept for automatic landing of a large parafoil developed for the European Space Agency was adopted by NASA for its X-38 Crew Return Vehicle parachute landing system [37, 38]. The same concept was used in the guided parafoil system developed by NASA for the US Army [39]. This concept features a trajectory planning in a wind-fixed reference frame. In this way, the trajectory can be planned as if there were no wind drift. The wind is assumed to be known in advance.

Jann [29, 40] proposes a similar concept. Here, the trajectory is also planned in the wind-fixed frame and the guidance is divided into three phases. The main difference is in the energy management (EM) phase: an adjustable T-shaped pattern is flown. Flight test results with this guidance scheme were presented in Jann [41].

A simpler approach is taken by Rademacher in reference [42]. During the first phase, the vehicle homes onto a waypoint directly above the target. Then, EM is performed by flying a racetrack pattern between two waypoints offset upwind and downwind from the target until the parafoil reaches certain altitude, after which the final homing to the target is executed. The waypoints are placed in an inertial frame of references; thus, no assumptions about the wind profile are needed. The exit from the EM phase is timed to accommodate the most adverse wind conditions.

Calise and Preston [30] describe a different scheme. Here, the guidance law also calls for several flight phases. However, the homing and EM phases are merged: first, most of the excess energy is disposed off by executing a spiral descent. Then, the remaining excess energy is regulated by performing s-turns along the way to the target. The wind profile is assumed to be known and the expected wind drift – the wind velocity integrated over the altitude-to-go – is taken into account during the computation of the desired altitude, although there is no explicit transformation into a wind-fixed frame.

Another approach is taken by Kaminer and Yakimenko in reference [43]. The main idea is to generate a single smooth reference trajectory that takes the parafoil from initial release point to touch down at a desired target. The shape of the trajectory is motivated by the solution to the minimal-time optimal control problem. Such a trajectory is shown to consist of helices and straight glide segments. However, the actual real-time trajectory generation is based on the problem geometry and parafoil performance without considering optimality. In essence, the trajectory consists of three segments resembling the three phases described above. Trajectory planning takes place in the inertial frame and the wind is treated as an unknown disturbance. However, it is not shown whether the parafoil can track the reference trajectory under such a disturbance.

A more recent guidance algorithm from Draper Laboratory [44] still includes the classical three phases with a figure-eight EM pattern, but the terminal phase (TP) implements an optimal guidance law – a heading rate command that minimizes a specific miss-distance-related function. This steering command is computed offline and tabulated in a sufficiently large neighbourhood of the target. It was reported recently that the optimization can be performed in real time aboard a 30 000 lbs class Megafly parafoil using a simplex search algorithm [45].

Slegers and Yakimenko [28] have recently presented a guidance algorithm for miniature parafoils. This concept divides the precision delivery mission into six phases. The trajectory is planned in the inertial frame and the four first phases are waypoint based. The most crucial for accurate landing is the fifth phase, which is a 180° turn to the final approach. Although the start of the turn is carefully timed, unmodelled winds and sensor errors can lead to large position errors at the end of this phase. Therefore, an optimal turn rate command is computed for this phase to satisfy the final conditions and minimize the error in time of arrival to the final approach point. As the vehicle may deviate from the desired path, the optimal trajectory is updated repeatedly during the final turn.

Another recent concept due to Rademacher et al. [32, 46] is to plan a smooth feasible reference trajectory for the entire mission [32, 46]. The path-planning problem is cast as a two-dimensional (2D) planning problem by a suitable change of the independent variable and formulated in the wind-fixed coordinate frame. A measure of excess energy, called an altitude margin, is derived and the reference trajectory is computed by the method based on the planar Dubins minimum-time path [47]. An alternate path planning method proposed is the optimal planning with fully specified final conditions that minimizes the control effort energy. An overall guidance strategy using both path generation methods and based on the altitude margin is also presented.

Thus, existing guidance concepts vary in their approach to trajectory planning. In most approaches, it is suggested to divide the mission into several phases. Some authors construct a waypoint- and heuristics-based trajectory, while others employ optimal control methods to trajectory planning. Several recent concepts combine both strategies during different flight phases. All reviewed works use GPS as the main source of navigation data.

Multiagent coordination, as applied to autonomous parafoils, was addressed in several works. Kaminer et al. [48] proposed a methodology for coordinated control of parafoils, where collision avoidance constraints were explicitly introduced during reference trajectory generation. Calise and Preston [30] used behaviour-based rules for coordination among the parafoils. Gurfil and Feldman [31] considered cooperative task management based on inter-parafoil ad hoc communication for increasing the probability of successful airdrop.

sec.title: 3 PARAFOIL MODELLING
sec.p: The first step is the development of the full parafoil models, from which the simplified models will be subsequently derived. The full models deal with a fully inflated parafoil wing assuming it is a rigid body. In the present scope, the whole parafoil–payload system is treated as a single rigid body, which requires integrating 6-DOF EOM. A more sophisticated approach is to treat the parafoil–payload system as a multibody problem, adding the DOFs for the relative motion, which would bring the total number of DOFs to 8 or 9. Nevertheless, a 6-DOF model has the capability to capture most of the important properties of the parafoil system and such models are commonly used [17, 25–28].

Building up a realistic parafoil model is a major challenge, since published parafoil aerodynamic data is scarce. Many sources have incomplete or inconsistent data, or data that applies only to specific parafoils [8–14]. The common practice for establishing a computational database for simulation is via parameter identification in flight tests [12, 13, 17, 25]. However, testing an actual parafoil was outside the scope of this research. The present model is based on the FASTWing CL parafoil [7]. It is based on the geometry, dimensions, weights, and some aerodynamic properties of the FASTWing CL system, but complete aerodynamic data was not available.

Working with 6-DOF EOM makes the modelling very similar to that of an airplane. The general references on the airplane EOM include references [49] and [50]. The following sections describe the 6-DOF model in detail.

A ram-air parachute is controlled by pulling the control lines attached to either outboard sections of the canopy trailing edge, which causes deflection of portions of the trailing edge, called also flap deflection or brake deflection [12, 19]. Right and left flap deflection are designated, respectively, by δr and δl. The differential flap deflection, defined here as δa ≜ δl − δr, produces asymmetric drag and causes the canopy to turn in the direction of the lower flap. Bank angle develops as a consequence of the turn rate due to a centrifugal force acting on the suspended payload. Such turn response is known as skid-to-turn. A symmetric deflection of flaps, δsΔ¯¯12(δl+δr), produces an increase in lift and drag coefficients, but the lift-to-drag ratio L/D and the trim angle of attack are usually affected only slightly; the significant increases in lift and drag coefficients result only in reduced velocity [19]. Controlling the glide slope by the means of symmetric trailing edge deflection is not feasible. Therefore, the main usage of symmetric flap deflection is for landing flare, in order to decrease horizontal and vertical velocities.

Trimming of a parafoil is achieved by rigging the suspension lines, which, in effect, determines the longitudinal position of the payload with respect to the canopy. The rigging angle, designated as Γ in Fig. 1, is analogous to the angle of incidence of fixed-wing aircraft. It is defined as the angle between the normal to the canopy chord and the line connecting the reference points of the canopy and the payload. It is convenient to define the body reference frame (see below) relative to the canopy chord, therefore xb in Fig. 1 is the longitudinal body axis and θ and α the pitch angle and the angle of attack, respectively. The rigging angle is usually fixed prior to deployment and is not variable in flight. Fig. 1
The rigging angle, pitch angle, and the angle of attack of parafoil

sec.title: 3.1 Equations of motion
sec.p: The following reference frames will be used in the subsequent developments.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Inertial frame
sec.p: This frame's origin is fixed on the Earth surface (assumed to be flat and non-rotating). The axes are oriented with the x-axis pointing north, the y-axis pointing east, and the z-axis pointing down. This coordinate system will be used as the inertial reference frame and is designated by n. In the parafoil guidance context, the origin will usually coincide with the landing location.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Body frame
sec.p: This axes system is fixed relatively to the parafoil and has its origin at the parafoil–payload system CG. The x-axis is aligned with the parafoil wing chord and points forward, the y-axis points to the right, and the z-axis points down. The body reference frame will be denoted by ‘b’. The EOM are integrated in this frame of reference.
The position of the parafoil–payload CG in the inertial reference frame will be denoted by (1)

Orientation of the body reference frame with respect to the inertial reference frame is given by the three Euler angles ϕ, θ, and ψ. Using the standard rotation sequence (ψ–θ–ϕ), the transformation from the inertial frame to the body frame is given by the matrix (2)
The inverse transformation is given by (3)

sec.title: 3.1.3 Wind frame (body carried)
sec.p: The wind-axis system has its origin at the CG – coincident with the body frame origin. However, the x-axis is aligned, at any given moment, with the velocity vector relative to the air mass. This reference frame is related to the body frame by rotations about the y-axis through the angle of attack and about the z-axis through the angle of sideslip. Thus, the transformation from body to wind axes is given by (4) The wind-axis reference frame is used for evaluation of the aerodynamic force coefficients.

sec.title: 3.1.4 Wind-fixed (atmosphere) frame
sec.p: This coordinate system moves with the air mass. At the time of landing, its origin coincides with the target. Orientation of the wind-fixed frame relatively to the inertial frame is fixed. The x-axis points to the desired landing heading (i.e. into the wind at the target) and the z-axis points down.

sec.title: 3.2 Kinematics and dynamics
sec.p: The inertial position x evolves in time according to (5) where v = [u, v, w]T is the inertial velocity expressed in the body reference frame. In addition (6) where ω = [p, q, r]T is the angular velocity in the body reference frame.

The equations of translational and rotational dynamics are given by (7) (8) where Faero and Maero are the aerodynamic forces and moments defined in subsequent paragraphs, g the gravity acceleration, m the vehicle mass and I the inertia matrix for a body with a single plane of symmetry given by (9)

This section presents the expressions for the body-axes aerodynamic forces and moments as a function of the non-dimensional aerodynamic coefficients. The assumption is that the force coefficients are given in the wind axes. The aerodynamic coefficients are usually evaluated at some reference point different from the CG.

Let r be the vector from the CG to the aerodynamics reference point. The aerodynamic forces and moments can be calculated as follows (10) (11) where ρ is the air density, V the airspeed, S the reference canopy area, b the wing span, c the mean aerodynamic chord, CL, CD, and CY the lift, drag, and side force coefficients, and Cl, Cm and Cn the rolling, pitching, and yawing moment coefficients.

sec.title: 3.3 Flight parameters and wind effects
sec.p: Wind effects are accounted for via the flight parameters used in the computation of the aerodynamic coefficients. Velocity of the parafoil relative to the air is given by (12) The true airspeed, V is the magnitude of va, V = ‖va‖, and the angle of attack and sideslip angle are computed as (13a) (13b)

sec.title: 3.4 Parafoil aerodynamics
sec.p: An initial source of aerodynamic data was the wind tunnel test report from the University of Notre Dame [10]. Another way of obtaining a computational database is using analytical approximations to calculate the aerodynamic coefficients.

The ram-air inflated canopy is typically shaped as a low-aspect-ratio wing with an arc-anhedral (Fig. 2). Application of Prandtl's lifting-line theory to this class of wings was treated in references [14, 16, 17]. According to Iosilevskii [14], the lift and drag coefficients can be approximated in the following way. Fig. 2
Geometry of parafoil with arc anhedral

Let the canopy span be denoted by b, the line length (arc radius) by R, and the canopy reference chord by c. The half-wing arc spread is given by (14) The projected span is therefore (15) and the projected canopy area (given a rectangular planform) is (16) Other useful definitions are the projected aspect ratio (17) the correction for wing curvature (18) the corrected profile lift curve slope (19) where a0 is the profile lift curve slope. The wing lift curve slope (20) the lift coefficient (21) the correction for non-elliptic lift distribution (22) the induced drag coefficient (23) and the total drag coefficient (24)

Apparent mass terms in the inertia matrix can account for changes in the momentum of surrounding air caused by the parafoil motion. For parafoils, the apparent mass effect is expected to be significant due to low wing loading and large distance between the lifting surface and centre of mass (CM) of the vehicle. The theory of apparent mass and methods for calculating the apparent mass of a parafoil are discussed in references [33] to [35]. However, experimentally measured aerodynamic data typically include the apparent mass effects. Due to uncertainty of available data, it was decided not to include apparent mass effects explicitly.
Thus, the computational database was compiled empirically, based on different sources. The aerodynamic coefficients are computed as follows (25a) (25b) (25c) (25d) (25e) (25f)

The moments of inertia were estimated according to a simple lumped-mass distribution model [14] (26a) (26b) (26c) (26d) where mc and mp are the masses of the canopy (including the air within its volume) and of the payload, respectively, xc and zc the horizontal and vertical locations of canopy CM and xp, zp the location of the payload CM.

sec.title: 3.5 Sensor and actuation models
sec.p:
The only sensors selected for the guidance and control algorithms presented in this article are a GPS receiver and an inertial measurement unit (IMU). The sensor models are based on the Aerosim Blockset [51]. The GPS model includes latency and slowly varying bias modelled as a Gauss–Markov process. The inertial sensors are modelled as second-order linear systems. Their error model consists of white noise and a varying bias. The IMU is assumed to be calibrated to compensate for constant and temperature-dependent biases. Effects of axis-non-orthogonality and acceleration-dependent bias are neglected. All sensor models include sampling and quantization effects. The sensor characteristics as modelled are generic and not represent any specific device. However, many sensors that meet or exceed assumed performance are commercially available; References [52] and [53] provide some examples. The parafoil is equipped with two control actuators for deflecting the flaps. The actuators are electric winches that reel up the control lines thereby deflecting the trailing edge of the canopy. Each actuator is modeled as a second-order linear system with a natural frequency of 30 rad/s and damping coefficient 0.7. Position limits and rate limit of 1 s for a full stroke are imposed.

sec.title: 3.6 Simplified steady-state model
sec.p: Solution of the trajectory design problem requires a simple, analytically tractable representation of the system. Since most of the flight, the parafoil is (nominally) in straight or turning equilibrium glide, such model can be constructed using only kinematic relationships and the parafoil steady-state performance data. Derivation of the quasi-steady model is rooted in the analysis of steady-state uncoordinated turn in a wind field.

As was mentioned previously, parafoils usually exhibit skid-to-turn (as opposed to bank-to-turn) behaviour. Deflection of one of the trailing edge flaps produces asymmetrical drag and causes a yawing moment in the direction of the lowered flap – in a conventional airplane, one would expect banking motion in the opposite direction. Bank angle develops as a consequence of the turn rate due to a centrifugal force acting on the suspended payload. The resulting turn is not coordinated; in the general case, Y ≠ 0 and β ≠ 0. That means that the bank angle (σ) of the force normal to the flight path (L′) is different from the body bank angle ϕ (Fig. 3). The angle σ will be referred to as the generalized bank angle. Fig. 3
A parafoil in turning flight

Let the direction of the velocity vector with respect to the wind be ξ. It is different from the parafoil heading angle ψ since ξ = ψ + β. However, β·=0 in equilibrium, therefore ξ·=ψ·. The position components of the parafoil evolve in time according to the kinematic equations (27a) (27b) (27c)
An equilibrium turning glide implies the condition V·=γ·=ξ··=0.

Considering the forces acting on the gliding parafoil (Fig. 4), for static equilibrium one obtains (28a) (28b) It follows that the equilibrium gliding angle can be found as (29) assuming L′/D ≈ L/D. The turn rate is given by (30) Fig. 4
Force diagram – side viewTo be able to propagate the EOM, one should determine L/D, σ, and V. For a given parafoil with a fixed rigging angle and a fixed symmetric flap deflection, these parameters can be expressed in terms of the differential flap deflection and the altitude (31a) (31b) (31c) Here, L/D(δa) is one of the parafoil characteristics. If σ0(δa) is the steady-state generalized bank angle at some given altitude, written as a function of the differential flap deflection, then σ at some other altitude can be approximated as (32) where ρ(h) is the air density as function of altitude and h0 the reference altitude.

Equation (29) gives the gliding angle as a function of the bank angle and, eventually, flap deflection. Let γ0 be the flight path angle in symmetric glide (33) Substituting L′ = 1/2ρV 2SCL′ and σ = 0 into (28b) yields (34) For σ ≠ 0 (35) Assuming CL′0 = CL′, yields (36) where V0 is the airspeed in straight glide. However, a parafoil trims at a constant lift coefficient, and hence the dynamic pressure is constant. Thus, it is convenient to specify the gliding airspeed in terms of the equivalent airspeed (37)

For the current parafoil model, the best gliding ratio is obtained with a 50 per cent symmetric flap deflection. This symmetric deflection will be considered nominal and referred to as the base flap deflection. The steering algorithm will command differential flap deflection around this base value: lowering one flap will occur along with raising the opposite one by the same angle. Such mode of control is beneficial also for lateral response as both flaps are not saturated; moreover, it helps to avoid control reversal typical for small flap deflections [12]. For the current model one can also assume that σ ≈ ϕ, which is convenient since ϕ is more readily identified from a 6-DOF simulation or from a test drop than σ. It can further be assumed, for the steering mode chosen, that L/D and σ0 depend linearly on δa.
From now on, the following data will be used

sec.title: 4 TRAJECTORY DESIGN, GUIDANCE, AND CONTROL
sec.p: In this section, the key building blocks of the trajectory design methodology are outlined.

sec.title: 4.1 Wind estimation
sec.p:
Determination of the wind vector is based on the equation (38) where vg is the inertial velocity vector, va the vector of velocity relative to the air, vw the wind velocity vector, and Cb n the body-to-inertial rotation matrix. This equation can be simplified by considering the horizontal velocity components only. From now on
and write the previous equation as (39) After neglecting the sideslip angle, the horizontal components of the velocity relative to the air are given by (40a) (40b) where ψ is the heading angle and V the airspeed magnitude. Thus, ideally, one needs to measure the ground speed vector, the true airspeed, and the heading angle in order to compute the wind velocity. If some of these measurements are not available and/or noisy, more sophisticated techniques should be employed.

Several observations can assist in selection of an appropriate wind estimation method for the present application. First, the wind speed is changing slowly and the estimation of its rapid fluctuations are not of interest. Second, the parafoil airspeed can be assumed constant with respect to the wind estimation time scale, except its deviations during turning flight. Moreover, the airspeed can be determined from the parafoil model. For a given canopy, the airspeed depends mostly on the rigged payload, and it is assumed that the load is always known prior to the mission.

When designing a wind estimation scheme for a parafoil system, the differences between a parafoil and a powered rigid aircraft must be kept in mind. Most importantly, the measurements of airspeed and attitude are complicated by low flight speeds and relative motion between the canopy, suspension lines, and the payload. Moreover, dedicated manoeuvres for wind estimation are sometimes impossible since they come on the expense of altitude. These are the reasons that render wind determination methods developed for powered uninhabited air vehicles not applicable to parafoils.

The above considerations lead to the investigation of an approach that would use GPS measurements only and would not employ dedicated manoeuvres. In theory, the wind components could be computed by solving a non-linear set of equations for the sum of velocities. If the airspeed is known, with GPS measurements for two time instances, there are four equations for two wind components (assuming that they remain unchanged between the measurements) and heading at two time instances – total of four variables. With three measurements, the airspeed can also be computed from six equations with six unknowns: two wind components, airspeed, and three headings. However, as noted by Jahn [40], this set of equations presents numerical problems and cannot be solved reliably in practice. Thus, Jahn [40] suggested two other approaches.
Measure ground speed, airspeed, and heading, subtract the airspeed vector from the ground speed vector, and apply a recursive mean filter to smooth the result.
Use only GPS ground speed data and apply a non-linear estimation filter based on the kinematic model (airspeed and heading are estimated as a by-product).

The second method was selected for implementation. At first, this method was employed without assuming a known airspeed. However, testing revealed problems with simultaneous estimation of the wind speed and the airspeed: the filter failed to converge to correct values. Consequently, the assumption of a known airspeed was adopted. The gliding velocity – in terms of equivalent airspeed, Veq – is constant for a given loading and rigging of the parafoil. This fixed airspeed is corrected during turns using the aerodynamic data and then converted it into the true airspeed using the GPS altitude. Under assumption of standard atmosphere, the true airspeed is given by the relation (41) where Veq(δa) is the equivalent airspeed as a function of the steering command as predicted by the simplified model described above and ρ the air density.

The estimator states are the wind velocity v∧w and heading ψ∧. Correction of the wind velocity estimate is given by (42) where Ke is the estimator gain and v∧g the predicted ground velocity given by (43) The estimated heading is corrected using the analytical heading derivative obtained as follows. By equations (39) and (40), the heading is given by (44) Taking the derivative (45) Substituting the estimated wind velocity into equation (45), one obtains the equation for the estimated heading rate (46) The ground velocity components vx and vy are measured by the GPS and the inertial accelerations vx· and vy· are approximated by numerical differentiation (wash-out).

The gain Ke can be made constant or adaptive. A fading gain that changes from an initial large value to a smaller value through some predefined time was implemented. The heading estimate is initialized to the measured ground track and the wind velocity estimate is initialized to the preloaded forecast velocity.

Figure 5 presents the results of wind estimation by the non-linear filter. In the cases shown, the parafoil flew a specific pattern consisting of straight legs and turns by the means of a simple waypoint-following algorithm. The tests included an ambient wind, Dryden turbulence, and measurement noise. The actual path flown was influenced by the wind and turbulence. Fig. 5
Example of a successful wind and heading estimation in the case of sufficient manoeuvring

In the test case shown in Fig. 5, the wind direction is from the east, becoming northeast as the parafoil descends; wind speed decreases at the same time. The parafoil is released heading north. The flight path as viewed from above is shown on the top-left plot. The filter manages to estimate the wind velocity and direction fairly well as shown on the bottom plots. The estimated heading is compared to the actual heading on the top-right plot.

sec.title: 4.2 The parafoil guidance problem
sec.p:
Guiding a descending parafoil to the planned landing spot involves planning a reference trajectory in space and making the parafoil follow this trajectory. The formal statement of the guidance problem is as follows:
Find a path from the initial configuration (x0, y0, h0, ψ0) to the final configuration (xf, yf, hf, ψf) under the constraints given by the parafoil EOM.The basic assumption is that a parafoil, at the time of its deployment, has enough energy to reach the target. A desired property of a reference trajectory is to spend the excess energy gradually and keep it roughly proportional to the remaining portion of the path. As evident in the literature survey, it is usually convenient to divide the guidance into the three phases of homing, (EM), and the (TP). Different trajectory shapes and guidance laws are appropriate for these portions of flight. Homing and the EM phase are commonly based on preplanned waypoints or heuristic rules, whereas for the TP, the trend is to use some form of optimal closed-loop trajectory planning, since this phase is responsible for minimizing the final miss distance. Thus, most of the research efforts are centred around the TP guidance. Alternatively, the entire flight can be viewed as a TP and a single continuous trajectory may be sought for.

The chosen trajectory planning strategy is based on Rademacher et al. [32, 46]. The algorithm can be summarized as follows. A kinematic model similar to the one described in section 3.6 is used. Substituting τ = h(t0) − h(t) as a new independent variable, allows planning the trajectory in the plane. Furthermore, the problem becomes a fixed-time problem. The EOM are transformed into the wind-fixed frame. Dubins' solution of the problem of shortest curves of bounded curvature in the plane [47] is applied next to determine the minimal altitude required to reach the target and compute the altitude margin. Whenever the altitude margin is positive, a feasible reference trajectory is generated as a modified Dubins' path.

The development in this section follows Rademacher et al. [32]. This study contributes a new implementation of Rademacher's path-planning method and evaluates it in a 6-DOF parafoil simulation. In a subsequent section, the path-planning method described here will be combined with behaviour-based rules for multiple parafoil coordination.

sec.title: 4.3 Change of the independent variable
sec.p: Define (47) Then, assuming without loss of generality that the target elevation is zero, h(tf) = 0, τ(t0) = 0, and τ(tf) = h(t0). Nominally, the altitude is strictly decreasing during gliding descent, and thus τ will be strictly increasing. Set τ as the new independent variable. Then (48) To distinguish between the time derivatives and the derivatives with respect to τ, the latter is denoted by (·)′. The system equations become (49a) (49b) (49c) As noted in Rademacher et al. [32], the change of variables offers two benefits. First, it reduces the order of the system by one, thus decreasing the computational cost of evaluating trajectories. Second, the final time τf becomes fixed for a given initial altitude, regardless of the trajectory.

sec.title: 4.4 Transformation to the wind-fixed frame
sec.p: The wind-fixed coordinate frame is a coordinate frame that moves with the air mass. If the trajectory is planned in this frame, the EOM will be further simplified by removing the wind drift. The origin of the inertial frame will be fixed at the target location with the x-axis pointing north. Let the wind-fixed frame have the same orientation as the inertial frame and locate its origin so that it coincides with the target at τ = τf. The position in this wind-fixed frame is given by (50a) (50b) Here, another benefit of using τ as the independent variable is evident, as the wind profile is easily expressed as a function of altitude. On the other hand, position in the wind-fixed frame at τ, expressed this way, depends explicitly on the velocity and the glide-path angle of the vehicle along the entire trajectory up to landing. As there are no means to determine these values before the trajectory is known, they can be approximated by the equilibrium glide values VG=Veq0(ρ(0)/ρ(h))1/2 and γ0, respectively. This will introduce another error in the transformation, in addition to the error resulting from imperfect knowledge of the wind. As pointed out in Rademacher et al. [32], choosing the equilibrium glide values will tend to overestimate the total drift due to the wind.

Now one can write the EOM in the wind-fixed frame (51a) (51b) (51c) In the subsequent trajectory synthesis procedure, the turn rate ξ′ will be considered a control input. The variable ξ′ is bounded due to the limitation on the flap deflection δa. Consequently, the turn is limited by a minimal radius, R.

sec.title: 4.5 Construction of the minimal-altitude-loss path
sec.p:
With the equations of motion put in a suitable form, one proceeds to define the measure of excess altitude, or the altitude margin, indicative of the difficulty to reach the target from a given position. In terms of equation (51), the minimal altitude loss is the minimal ‘time’ τmin required for transition from the initial configuration Ξ0 = (xw0, yw0, ξ0) to the final configuration Ξf = (0, 0, ξf). τmin corresponds to the minimal length of the path from Ξ0 to Ξf. The problem of finding the shortest path of this type was solved in 1957 by Dubins [47], who showed that it
is necessarily a continuously differentiable curve which consists of not more than three pieces, each of which is either a straight line segment or an arc of a circle of radius R.To be more specific, the shortest path is given by one of the following six control sequences: RSR, RSL, LSR, LSL, LRL, or RLR, where R corresponds to a maximum right-hand turn, L a maximum left-hand turn, and S a straight line. These trajectories are referred to as Dubins paths. The same solution was obtained again by Boissonnat et al. [54] using the Pontryagin minimum principle.

The goal is finding the cost of the shortest path in terms of altitude loss, as well as the point Ξ*(τ)=(xw *(τ),yw *(τ),ξ*(τ)) lying on the path for any given value of τ. This is accomplished by construction of all six candidate curves and selection of the shortest one. The process is illustrated in Fig. 6. First, construct the four possible turn circles for given initial and final positions. For each pair of circles, find all common tangents, compute points of tangency and tangent directions. Then, select those that coincide with the flight direction for the origin circle and for the destination circle – only such tangents are shown in Fig. 6. This will leave us with at most one feasible RSR/RSL/LSR/LSL path for each pair of circles. If possible, construct a middle circle tangent to both circles to get RLR and LRL paths. Now, compute the cost of all the candidate paths and select the optimal one. The cost of each of the four candidate paths in the example is shown in Fig. 6 and the optimal path is plotted as a bold line. A case with RLR candidate paths is illustrated in Fig. 7; however, they are not optimal in this case. In case of Fig. 8, the LRL path is optimal. Fig. 6
Dubins path construction process Fig. 7
Dubins path construction – with RLR candidate paths Fig. 8
Dubins path construction – LRL path is optimal

The above process yields the minimal altitude τmin. The altitude required to make a 360° turn is denoted by τ360. The altitude margin will be defined as (52) This definition provides us with a necessary condition for existence of a path from Ξ0 to Ξf (53) Several notes should be made about the minimal-altitude-loss path.
In general, the minimal turn radius depends on the altitude, so the candidate paths cannot be constructed before the cost is known and vice versa. To avoid this complication, it is assumed that the turn radius is constant.
In some cases, much shorter paths could be found if some error in the final conditions was allowed. Since the final conditions are rigidly fixed, a slight change in initial conditions can force the algorithm to switch to a much longer path.
Instant switching between the trajectory segments is not possible due to the vehicle dynamics. However, if the turn radius leaves some manoeuvring margin, the vehicle can reconverge to the desired path if it deviates from it at some point. That is why the available command is limited to δa ∈ [−0.8, 0.8] for path planning, i.e. to 80 per cent of the full stroke, and use a corresponding minimal turn radius – 180 m in the case of the present parafoil.

sec.title: 4.6 Construction of the modified dubins path
sec.p: Whenever η > 0, the optimal path itself is not useful, since it will leave the parafoil with excess altitude above the target. Thus, one has to seek a trajectory that will deal with the excess altitude. A straightforward way proposed in Rademacher et al. [32] is to modify the optimal Dubins path: generate a similar trajectory, but using a larger radius than the minimal turn radius.
The modified path computation algorithm is laid out as follows. The minimal time τmin corresponds to the minimal turn radius R. The task is to find r* > R such that τ(r* ) = τf.

list-item.p: For a given r, the above minimum-time path procedure yields τ(r)
Starting with rmin, double the radius until τ(r) > τf
Use the bisection method to converge on r*

sec.p:
An example of a modified Dubins path for different initial values of η is shown in Fig. 9. A practical implementation of this method poses some difficulties since the function τ(r) is not continuous in r. Thus, for some given initial conditions, there is no modified path solution of this type. This is due to the fact that the search is limited to a certain family of curves, whereas the solution – that should exist for η > 0 – may be of another type. The problem is particularly pronounced close to the target. Two ways are proposed for dealing with this complication. The first one is to compute another feasible path, e.g. a minimum-control-effort path; another way is to use heuristics in order to circumvent the problem. Fig. 9
Modified Dubins paths

sec.title: 4.7 Fixed-time optimal control formulations
sec.p: When the altitude loss constraint is inactive and the modified Dubins path generation fails, other optimality criteria can be used for trajectory generation. A reasonable choice for the optimization criterion is the control energy. First, the case of fixed initial and final conditions is examined, with a running cost on control effort only. The following development appears also in Rademacher et al. [32]. In this case, one is solving a standard optimal control problem that can be stated as follows. Determine the control u(τ) = ξ′(τ) for τ ∈ [0, τf], where τf is fixed, which minimizes the performance index (54) subject to the kinematic constraints of the system (51) with prescribed initial and final configurations, Ξ0 and Ξf, respectively.

The Hamiltonian for this problem is given by (55) where λx, λy, and λξ are costates. By the Pontryagin minimum principle (56a) (56b) (56c) (56d) It is assumed here that γ is constant and is not dependent on u and τ. One can now express λξ and u in terms of λxyw and λyxw. From equation (56d) (57) Since λx and λy are constant by equations (56b,c), integrating equation (57) yields (58) where c is a constant of integration. Equations (56a) and (47) yield (59) λx and λy are constant, therefore the general form of the control is (60) The constants c1, c2, and c3 can be found by solving a non-linear boundary value problem (BVP) (61a) (61b) (61c) with boundary conditions at τ0 and τf fully specified. Unfortunately, this BVP is not known to have an analytical solution. References [32] and [46] mention a numerical solution, but it was not implemented in this article.

Another case of the minimum-control-energy formulation involves free final conditions, a running cost on the control effort, and a terminal cost on the final position error. In this case, the solution does not change substantially; essentially, the same BVP is obtained.

Minimizing the control effort is not the only possible objective for optimal trajectory design. Another option is minimizing the total distance travelled or time spent in flight, as this will also reduce sensitivity to unknown winds. This effectively amounts to flying with the worst aerodynamic efficiency that will still allow reaching the target, or minimizing ∫0 τfL/D(δa)cosσdτ. This formulation will lead to bang-bang control – the path consisting of minimal-radius arcs.

sec.title: 4.8 Implementing the trajectory generation
sec.p:
The algorithm implemented in simulation generates the modified Dubins path. The flowchart of the algorithm is presented in Fig. 10. The computation should proceed through the following steps.
Using existing wind data (forecast or extrapolation of estimated wind), transform the vehicle position to the wind frame.
Compute the Dubins path leading to (0, 0) position above the target at upwind heading and obtain the altitude margin.
Recompute the Dubins path repetitively and reassess the altitude margin.
Attempt to compute a modified Dubins path to the target. If the computation converges, this will be the reference path; otherwise, the Dubins path to the holding point will be flown and the modified path computation will be attempted repetitively.
The reference trajectories are initially given in terms of the geometric trajectory elements: arc centres, radii, points of tangency. Transform the reference trajectory to (xw, yw) as a function of altitude. Other reference flight parameters such as heading, turn rate, control input are also computed.
Using sensor data, compute the cross-range (lateral) and downrange (longitudinal) tracking error and the rate of convergence to the path.
The lateral tracking controller shall command required control deflections as a function of the tracking error and reference data. The downrange error can be reduced by changing the turn radius and trading off lateral tracking.
If the downrange error grows above a predefined threshold, recompute the reference trajectory from the actual vehicle position. The guidance will switch to the new trajectory only if the solution has converged with a positive altitude margin.
Fig. 10
Flowchart of the trajectory generation algorithm

sec.title: 4.9 Simulation results
sec.p: This section summarizes the simulation results for the trajectory planning and guidance of a single parafoil. The following results were obtained using the 6-DOF parafoil simulation including sensor errors described in section 3.5 and Dryden turbulence.

Figure 11 shows a top view of a wind-free trajectory. The initial conditions for this case were x0 = 1000 m, and y0 = 2000 m, h0 = 1000 m, and ψ0 = 180°. Trajectories in inertial coordinates and wind coordinates are identical. The discontinuities that can be seen in the reference trajectory occur due to re-planning of the trajectory whenever the parafoil deviates from the original reference by more than 50 m. The main cause for these deviations is the turbulence. Fig. 11
Trajectory for a sample no-wind case

The altitude margin, η, decreases during the descent, being positive most of the time. Shortly before landing, the altitude margin becomes negative, indicating that the exact target location cannot be reached anymore. This is a typical behaviour since some deviation from the reference trajectory always exists, and at a low altitude and short range from the target, it cannot be corrected within the manoeuvring limits of the parafoil. In such a case, the parafoil retains the last valid reference trajectory. The reference trajectory passes exactly through the target. However, the parafoil slightly overshoots and lands about 28 m away from the target.

Figure 12 presents the trajectory for a case with constant and known wind of 10 m/s from a 270° heading. The initial conditions are x0 = 1000 m, y0 = −2000 m, h0 = 1000 m, and ψ0 = 0°. This time, the difference between the inertial frame and the wind frame trajectories is clearly visible. The landing miss distance is 31 m. Fig. 12
Trajectory with known wind

Finally, Monte Carlo simulation results evaluating the landing dispersion are presented. Two batches of 200 runs each were performed: with downtrack feedback (dx) and without it. The Monte Carlo simulation was performed in zero wind conditions from random initial positions within 2000 m from the target and altitude of 1000 m. The turbulence and sensor errors were present in all the simulation runs. Figures 13 and 14 show the landing locations of the two batches. In each figure, the CEP is compared to a 100 m radius circle. The results show the benefit of using dx feedback. With this feedback, 75 per cent of the landings take place within the 100 m circle and the CEP is 65.4 m. In the other case, only 62 per cent of the landings were inside the 100 m circle and the CEP was 83 m. Fig. 13
Landing dispersion with dx feedback Fig. 14
Landing dispersion without dx feedback

sec.title: 5 MULTIPLE PARAFOIL FLOCKING
sec.p: Undoubtedly, precision guidance of parafoils to their intended target must rely on individual trajectory planning by each vehicle. Nevertheless, in a mass airdrop scenario, flocking (as an additional guidance layer) offers several potential benefits. Flocking among the parafoils aimed for the same landing spot can reduce touch-down dispersion, at the same time mitigating risk of collisions. It is expected that flocking will help the parafoils to fly on more similar trajectories, indirectly averaging out the wind estimation errors. Flocking can also assist the vehicles that fail to achieve a valid trajectory solution.

However, flocking among parafoils poses several interesting challenges. Parafoils are different from powered aircraft in many aspects of flocking. First, parafoils cannot manoeuvre in the vertical plane or directly control their altitude. Next, there is little control over the horizontal speed. These two limitations restrict possible manoeuvres to horizontal (or, rather, descending) turns. In addition, large and heavy parafoils considered in this study are characterized by a low maximum turn rate and large turn radii. Turn radii of the order of hundreds of metres together with large canopy span necessitate a large safety distance among the vehicles. Considering the required landing dispersion of less than 100 m CEP, such parafoil properties severely limit flocking performance and diminish the possible benefits from flocking.

To obtain a behaviour that would appear as flocking among parafoils, each vehicle in the flock should make lateral steering corrections as a function of a 3D metric on the local flock configuration. The parafoil behaviour will be comprised by the three classical rules of cohesion, separation, and alignment. The ways of implementing these rules are numerous. In the remaining part of this section and in the next section, a new class of flocking algorithms are developed for parafoils that implement Reynolds' flocking rules.

At the same time, local neighbourhood can be defined either as all vehicles within a specified sensing zone of own parafoil (R-neighbourhood), or as N nearest vehicles regardless of their position (N-neighbourhood). N-neighbourhood can optionally be also limited by the maximum range from own vehicle. The two definitions of the neighbourhood are depicted in Fig. 15. Fig. 15
Local neighbourhood

It is customary to define the action – attraction or repulsion – vector as the reciprocal gradient of the potential field induced by the flock configuration [55, 56]. A potential function is not explicitly defined; instead, action vectors with desired properties are directly defined. An action vector may produce both attraction and repulsion, or one of them. Since cohesion and separation are the two necessary basic behaviours, at least one source of each kind of force is needed. By combining two definitions of the flock configuration with different definitions of action vectors, nine different flocking strategies, summarized in Table 2, can be obtained. Figure 16 illustrates some of the combinations. Fig. 16
Flocking strategy: possible ways to define the action vector

However, only some of the possible combinations are practical. On one hand, separation cannot rely solely on centroid-based repulsion. To illustrate this, one can imagine two parafoils flying at the desired distance from the centroid and experiencing neither repulsion nor attraction while being dangerously close to each other, as shown in Fig. 16(a). On the other hand, cohesion can be achieved with either definition of the flock configuration and it would be redundant to use both at the same time. Thus, combinations 2, 3, and 5 out of the nine possible combinations are being focused on the following.
Sum of flockmate-based attraction/repulsion vectors responsible for both cohesion and separation.
Sum of centroid-based attraction vector responsible for cohesion only and flockmate-based repulsion vectors responsible for separation.
Sum of centroid-based attraction/repulsion vector responsible for both cohesion and separation and flockmate-based repulsion vectors responsible for separation.

Alignment. The trajectory-following guidance command may enforce the rule of velocity alignment, provided the parafoils fly on trajectories of similar shape. However, if the reference trajectories are not alike, velocity matching will not be obtained. Then, this rule should be implemented explicitly. In this case, only the velocities of parafoils close enough to own vehicle should be taken into account.

For each of the described alternatives, there are several design decisions to make.
Select the exact definition of the local neighbourhood (R- or N-neighbourhood).
Choose parameters R and/or N.
Define the action vector function.
Define the guidance law transforming the action vector into steering commands.
Select the weights for combining the steering commands of each flocking rule with those of the reference trajectory guidance.

sec.title: 5.1.1 Centroid and average velocity calculation
sec.p: Let n denote the number of vehicles within the local neighbourhood, and let (62) be the position of the ith vehicle in the local neighbourhood, with x0 being the own vehicle position. The relative position of the ith neighbour with respect to the own vehicle is given by (63) and the position of the local flock centroid is calculated as (64) The sum of position vectors in equation (64) is divided by n + 1 to take into account own position, x0 l, which is [0, 0, 0]T by equation (63). xi h will denote the ith vehicle relative position in the horizontal plane and, similarly, xc h the centroid position in the horizontal plane.

The velocities are treated in a similar way. Let vectors v0 and vi denote the horizontal velocities of the own parafoil and of the ith neighbour in the Earth's axis. The relative velocity of the ith neighbour is given by (65) and the average flock velocity along the Earth's axis is computed as (66) Then, the average velocity is transformed into the ground-track axes by (67) where χ is the own ground track.

sec.title: 5.1.2 Action vectors
sec.p: A smooth action vector providing both attraction and repulsion is defined in the horizontal plane. Its direction is along the horizontal direction to the local centroid, or to the corresponding flockmate, and its magnitude and sign are designed to produce (a) zero force at some nominal equilibrium range, (b) hyperbolically growing repulsion as the range approaches zero, and (c) linearly-growing attraction as the range increases beyond the equilibrium value.

Consider a family of 2D vector-valued functions (68) where ka, re, and p are parameters and ‖ · ‖ is the Euclidean norm. This function family has the following properties:
If ka = 1, re > 0 and p ⩾ 1, f represents either an attractive or a repulsive force:
‖f‖ = 0 if, and only if, ‖xc‖ = re. In this case, re is the equilibrium range;
When ‖xc‖ tends to zero, f acts from the centroid and ‖f‖ → ∞;
When ‖xc‖ >> re, f acts towards the centroid and ‖f‖ → ‖xc‖.
If ka = 0, re > 0 and p ⩾ 1, f represents a repulsive force, growing hyperbolically as the range ‖xc‖ approaches zero.
If ka > 0 and re = 0, f represents an attractive force, growing linearly with the range.
For flockmate-based action vector, xc and xc h are replaced by xi l and xi h, respectively. Note, that xi l,xc∈R3, i.e. include the vertical separation between the parafoils, whereas xi h,xc h∈R2.

sec.title: 5.1.3 Steering commands
sec.p: At this stage, there is either a single action vector fr for rth flocking rule, or n vectors fri, i ∈ [1, n]. In the latter case, the contributions of all the neighbours are added (69) Then, a scalar weight wr for each rule is defined and the contributions of all the rules are added (70) Let ψf be the orientation angle of the flocking vector f and χ the ground track of the vehicle. The course error is defined by (71)

The flocking steering command δf is composed from the contributions of the action-vector-driven command and the alignment command. Both sources of the steering command are 2D vectors. They are transformed to a scalar command in a similar way: by a product of their orientation and their magnitude. The overall command is computed as a weighted sum of two components (72) where kforce and kalign are parameters. Finally, the flocking steering command is combined with a trajectory-tracking command using flocking weight wf and trajectory weight wt (73) where δt is the output of the trajectory-tracking controller.

sec.title: 5.2 Flocking simulation results
sec.p:
Five variations of the flocking strategy were investigated.
Flockmate-based attraction/repulsion, N-neighbourhood, N = 2.
Centroid-based attraction/repulsion, N-neighbourhood, N = 2 and repulsion from the nearest vehicle (flockmate-based, N-neighbourhood, N = 1).
Centroid-based attraction/repulsion, N-neighbourhood, N = 2 and flockmate-based repulsion, N-neighbourhood, N = 2.
Centroid-based attraction, N-neighbourhood, N = 2 and repulsion from the nearest vehicle (flockmate based, N-neighbourhood N = 1).
Centroid-based attraction, N-neighbourhood, N = 2 and flockmate-based repulsion, N-neighbourhood, N = 2.

All of the above variations include the alignment rule based on R-neighbourhood with R = 500 m. Alignment behaviour was found to be essential, serving as a damping coefficient during flocking. Since prior to flocking the parafoils have no means for agreeing about a common trajectory, the reference trajectory cannot serve as an external migration vector for aligning the velocities of the parafoils.

A difficulty arises with simultaneous flocking and trajectory following since the two guidance laws produce conflicting control demands. This problem has to be solved by a suitable control allocation. A somewhat unexpected conclusion was reached: For satisfactory guidance performance, one has to give the flocking commands priority over the tracking ones. This is due to the fact that flocking is a continuous process, whereas trajectory tracking is tolerant to deviations: if the vehicle veers off its path, a new trajectory is generated from the new position. Thus, once the flock has converged, the flocking frees the control for the path following. On the contrary, if the parafoil struggles to find its equilibrium position in the flock, the control can remain saturated for a long time. As a consequence, the parafoil will be carried too far away to reach the target, without any control over its trajectory.

Flocking is possible only if there is enough excess altitude to spare during gathering. In the present implementation, priority is given to flocking by limiting the trajectory-tracking command before summation with the flocking command. The flocking command is not limited, whereas the total command is limited again after the summation.

Even with the control allocation problem solved, however, the parafoils, as a flock, cannot land at the same spot. It was seen in simulation that minimal practical separation for parafoils of the kind studied is about 100 m. Therefore, if large number of parafoils are dropped and come for landing as a flock, some vehicles will land several hundred metres off the target. This effect is apparent from the simulation results.

In general, the flocking process is highly non-linear. No formal stability analysis was done in the present scope. However, convergence properties were proved for similar algorithms in published studies – e.g. referebces [55] and [56]. In particular, Olfati-Saber [56] proved for a group of agents applying an algorithm that embodies Reynolds' flocking rules that under certain conditions (a) the structural dynamics converges to an equilibrium; (b) the velocities of all agents asymptotically match; and (c) no inter-agent collisions occur. Olfati-Saber [56] also indicated that for a generic set of initial states and a large number of agents, the Reynolds' algorithm is likely to lead to flock fragmentation.

All the five described algorithm variations produced reasonable flocking after tuning of their parameters. Table 3 summarizes the parameter values for the five strategies. Table 3

Landing dispersion under combined trajectory-tracking and flocking laws was evaluated in a Monte Carlo simulation. Two batches were performed for each algorithm: one does not include atmospheric disturbances and sensor errors, whereas the other includes turbulence and sensor noise. In all of the batches, the parafoils were deployed at random positions and headings within 2000 m from the target and at an altitude of 2000 m. ( The range from the target was distributed uniformly between 0 and 2000 m and both the bearing from the target and the heading angle were distributed uniformly between 0° and 360°.) In each case, six parafoils were deployed and assigned the same target (located at the origin). Although the batches consist of a relatively small number of runs (between 15 and 60), the statistics are supported by another simulation session.

Figure 17 presents the landing dispersion in CEP values for individual parafoils for each of the five algorithms. The superiority of Algorithm 5 can be observed. In the absence of disturbances, the fifth variation achieves CEP of 73 m, comparable with that of the basic guidance algorithm without flocking. The diagram also shows strong influence of the turbulence and sensor errors on the scatter. However, the trend among the different algorithms remains unchanged. Fig. 17
CEP values for five flocking variations

Additional measure of the flocking performance is the miss distance of a group of the parafoils, landing as a flock. Figure 18 shows the mean miss distance of the flock centroid. The very low value for Algorithm 5 (44 m) indicates that most of the total scatter should be attributed to the separation among the parafoils in the flock. The landing dispersion for Algorithms 3 and 5 is depicted in Fig. 19. The circles around the target show the CEP of each batch. Finally, sample trajectories of a flock of six parafoils flying under Algorithm 5 are presented. A case of correct flocking and guidance is shown in Fig. 20. Figure 21 shows a case in which the parafoils gather into two separated components of three vehicles, each of them tracking another trajectory. This is an example of fragmentation mentioned above. It occurs because of the limited number of flockmates included in the local neighbourhood of each parafoil. In the present implementation, this number is two. Hence, if a component of three parafoils is formed, in which the parafoils are attracted to each other, there will be no cohesion between these three parafoils and the rest of the flock. In the case shown, since both groups approach the target at the same time, the flock joins before the parafoils begin to land. Fig. 18
Mean distance of the flock centroid from the target Fig. 19
Flocking Monte Carlo simulation: landing dispersion Fig. 20
Sample flocking trajectories for Algorithm 5 Fig. 21
Flocking trajectories for Algorithm 5 showing the fragmentation phenomenon

To summarize the simulation results, one can make several observations. In most cases tested, the parafoils were able to establish flocking and also land close to their intended target. All three basic behaviours are essential for correct flocking and all five flocking algorithms can establish and maintain a flock. However, flocking motion resulting from different algorithms can appear visually very different and lead to different levels of landing dispersion. Safe separation among the parafoils is maintained during flocking.

Comparison between the flocking algorithms, won by Algorithm 5, shows that the best results are obtained with centroid-based cohesion and flockmate-based separation. In addition, it is beneficial to base the separation on more than one flockmate, such as done in Algorithm 5.

There are several suggestions that may help to increase the benefit from integrating a flocking behaviour with parafoil guidance algorithms. One idea is to elect in distributed manner one vehicle to execute guidance to the target without flocking. Thus, this vehicle will become a flock leader. One possible choice of a leader is a vehicle that reports itself healthy and has the lowest positive altitude margin. The choice of a leader might change during flight. Another proposition is to use the flocking rules for collision avoidance only. In such a case, only separation and alignment laws will be used. Cohesion will not be required since each parafoil will navigate to the target by itself.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Comparison of five variations of the flocking strategy shows that the best combined flocking and tracking performance is obtained with centroid-based cohesion and flockmate-based separation. The overall landing dispersion with flocking is higher than in the case of trajectory tracking alone due to separation of the parafoils in the flock. However, with more advanced cooperation among the flocking parafoils, there is a potential to improve the landing accuracy.

The main contributions of this study are the development of flocking rules for cooperative parafoils and validation of these rules by simulation. In the simulation, the parafoils were able to gather into a flock and maintain the flock while gliding to the target. The simulation results confirm the feasibility of tracking a reference trajectory and flocking simultaneously, thus avoiding collisions among the parafoils. The main conclusion is that cooperation among autonomous parafoils, can make airdrop a more efficient and reliable way of delivering critical supplies exactly where they are needed.
